awd_titl_txt: Assessing the Impact of Teaching Faculty in STEM Institutional Transformation
awd_abstract_narration:
While recent advances in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education research have highlighted promising instructional practices to improve undergraduate education, widespread dissemination of these practices remains difficult to achieve at most institutions.  One method which may help to accomplish this is to embed teaching-focused faculty within STEM departments.  An example of such teaching-focused faculty are those holding positions as Lecturer with Security of Employment (LSOE), a tenure-track faculty position within the University of California system.  The important purpose of this project is to measure the impact of faculty in this kind of position at the departmental and institutional levels.  This study will be one of the most expansive attempts to measure institutional teaching culture, in terms of classroom practice, faculty interactions, and perceptions of instructional practices, across not only multiple STEM departments, but multiple institutions within a connected university system. The study will also analyze the role that LSOEs play in fostering departmental-level collaborations about instruction and in impacting departmental research productivity. The results of this study will indicate whether whether this LSOE faculty track can be a means worthy of consideration in STEM programs at other institutions to increase the spread of evidence-based teaching practices. 

The goal of the project is to institute an assessment plan to (1) determine the impact of LSOEs on transforming instruction across various STEM disciplines at three UC campuses (Irvine, San Diego, and Davis) which have recently recruited large numbers of LSOEs and (2) demonstrate that the assessment methodologies described in the project can be used for the general purpose of departmental and institutional evaluation of teaching. The proposed methodologies include social network analysis, classroom observations, distribution of surveys regarding teaching practices, collection of departmental publication and funding numbers, and interviews with UC stakeholders and LSOEs regarding expectations of teaching faculty.  By illustrating that it is possible to utilize these methods in combination to assess institutional education practices, results from this work will lay the groundwork for similar studies at other universities.

por.por_cntn:
It has been well-documented that science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) higher education programs are plagued by less equitable outcomes for Latinx and Black students, among others. Recent evidence highlights classroom practices and institutional policies that can create more inclusive learning experiences, though the adoption of these practices at a wide scale has yet to occur. One potential means to transform the higher education experience is through teaching-focused faculty, individuals with expertise within their STEM field whose primary responsibility is geared towards the education, as opposed to the research, mission of the university. The most common type of teaching-focused faculty is the adjunct lecturer, a group which evidence commonly shows to be highly effective, yet plagued by issues that often result in those in the position being perceived as second-class citizens. A hybrid of the adjunct lecturer and the traditional research-focused professor within the University of California is the Lecturer with Potential Security of Employment (L(P)SOE), commonly referred to as the Professor of Teaching (PoT). The PoT is a tenure-track, teaching-focused position, that we investigated through this National Science Foundation grant, as individuals that could potentially serve as change agents to improve the quality and inclusivity of STEM education programs.


In this work, we aimed to (1) characterize the PoT position and the individuals who serve in this role and (2) identify the impacts of PoTs through interviews of university administrators and examinations of departmental communication networks. Through a survey of PoT faculty across the University of California, we found that while these individuals are primarily trained within their discipline (i.e. biology, chemistry, etc) and not an education field, they do possess considerable classroom teaching experience and have participated in informal professional development activities. The position also appears to be evolving, as more recent PoT hires felt an increased expectation to engage in scholarly activities, including conducting research on teaching and learning in higher education. This finding aligned with interview data collected from college deans, department chairs, and hiring committee chairs. These administrators praised the PoTs on their campus for the high quality of their teaching, their influence on their departmental colleagues as instructional resources, and their abilities to secure external grant funding for education-related endeavors. These interviews also highlighted potential barriers to the success of PoTs, including a lack of resources for them to engage in scholarly activities and a perception amongst some departmental colleagues that they are not seen as equals, similar to the plight of the adjunct lecturer. We also examined the position of PoTs within departmental discussions regarding research and teaching through social network analysis. Despite being only 10% of the faculty within a department, PoTs are integral players in teaching discussions and sources of advice for teaching related matters both within a department and between departments. 


These findings hint towards a potential role for the PoT as an educational change agent. Follow-up studies will collect classroom observation data, to identify whether PoTs are more likely to implement inclusive practices, student grade data, to identify whether instruction from PoTs leads to improved learning, and student survey data measuring attitudes and sense of belonging, to identify whether PoTs create more inclusive classroom environments. We are also in the process of generating guides for the hiring and support of PoT faculty to increase the success of these individuals within the University of California system, as well as to inform administrators at other colleges and universities looking to adopt similar faculty positions in order to better support the success of the next generation of STEM leaders.
